utterances: By Saturday, a daylong party was in full swing.
The police had visited just once to advise organizers to keep the numbers down.
On stage, one of China's top jazz singers was in drag as Cocolicious, wearing a white silk dress and lots of bling, and dueting with a woman in a snazzy black tux and pink trilby.
This is quite important, not only for me, but for China, for the whole world.
It is a great statement of how China's gay scene is ballooning right now.
For Cocolicious and a generation of younger gays, sexuality has clearly nothing to do with the state.
I love my country.
I would do anything to protect my country, as well, so I don't think there's anything will get me in trouble.
If I dress up like a girl once in a while and being homosexuality, I think that's something my personal.
Okay, we've got Fiona for 300.
Ladies, come on.
As people are auctioned for charity, the crowd is in great spirits.
But underlying that is caution born of past disappointments.
Several interviewees requested their jobs aren't mentioned for fear of retribution.
Yu Tian is celebrating, his face painted with a rainbow.
He's happy, but says what we're seeing isn't true openness.
(Through Translator) I think this gay pride festival is allowed because it's organized by foreigners.
When Chinese people try to do things like this, they often get closed down.
In Beijing, three times the queer film festival was closed on its opening day.
But today, however, the mood is one of celebration.
But China's gay men and women know they have battles ahead.
One of the earliest could be against the Internet filtering software, which must be provided with all new computers from the July 1st.
This blocks access to any sites using the word homosexual -at a stroke blacklisting those gay community Web sites that helped make Shanghai gay pride week a reality.
Louisa Lim, NPR News, Shanghai.
It's Thursday, which is when we often read from your e-mail.
We got a wave of letters in response to our interview with Congressman Rahm Emanuel, the head of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.

Even though Democrats have made some proposals, as you point out...
Right.
...do you think that...
Let's say I have high blood pressure.

Well, it's normal for me to be followed for my blood pressure and response to medications, and as part of those visits, one can easily incorporate other preventive measures that are appropriate for me, given my age and gender and other risk factors, rather than having a separate visit that's quote, ""the annual physical.
One reason is that automatically testing healthy people can cause problems.
If I do 20 laboratory tests on a blood panel, you know, the odds are quite high that one of them is going to be abnormal, and this could be just a random fluctuation.
And yet when there's an abnormal lab test, often that results in a cascade of additional testing.
That can cost a patient time, money and undue concern.
But internist Alan Pocinki hasn't found that in his own practice.
I think that's more of a theoretical concern than a practical concern.
Yeah, occasionally you run chemistry profiles and you'll see something's a little high or something's a little low.
But based on the patient's symptom and their other results and their examination findings, you'll make a decision whether it's significant or not.
He says just because there's no proof an annual physical is helpful doesn't mean it's not.
And he says it's hard to incorporate screening and prevention advice when someone comes in with, say, the flu.
They may not be receptive to preventive-care counseling at that time.
They may not ready to talk about that.
They're sick.
They don't feel well.
And insurance often won't cover things like preventive-care counseling as part of a sick visit.
Meanwhile, Pocinki's patient, Greg Fedder, leaves happy.
All right.
Thanks.
Good to see you.
Thank you.

He says he'll be back next year.
I get a sense that, you know, things are on track and that anything major would be caught.
I'm not looking for complete and total satisfaction.
I'm just looking for a reasonable level that nothing major is wrong with me.
There is, of course, the issue of price.
Fedder's care was covered by his health insurance.
Ninety-three percent of workers with employer-based insurers are covered, too, according to a Kaiser Family Foundation survey.
But for others, it can be a costly experience.
Fedder's doctor says he charges about 350 to $400 for the average annual physical with laboratory testing.

And we begin today with a new intelligence report on al-Qaida and the threat it poses to the United States.
Among the headlines in that report, al-Qaida will step up efforts to put operatives inside the U.S., and it has rebuilt a secure sanctuary along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border.

The report, prepared by the nation's top intelligence analysts, is also prompting questions as to the exact nature of the relationship between Osama bin Laden's terror network and its affiliate group in Iraq.
Here's NPR's Mary Louise Kelly.

There is some good news in this report and it judges that al-Qaida does not currently have active cells in the U.S., and the report finds that counterterrorism efforts over the past five years have constrained al-Qaida's ability to attack the U.S.
But the report's lead author, Ted Gistaro of the National Intelligence Council says, al-Qaida leaders desire to attack the U.S.
is quote, ""undiminished,"" and they are thinking big.
We did come to consensus that when it comes to the homeland, the al-Qaida leadership remains focused on high-profile, high-impact attacks.
Things that will cause a lot of casualties and that will have a number of social, economic and political aftershocks.
This morning, as Gistaro and other intelligence officials were briefing reporters, the White House was gearing up for its own press conference on the report.
The president's Homeland Security Advisor Frances Townsend seized on the National Intelligence Estimate, or NIE, as evidence that al-Qaida remains a determined enemy that must be defeated.
The information in these reports is not new.
On the contrary, the NIE reinforces the seriousness of the terrorist threat against the homeland, and confirms much what the president has been saying since September the 11th.
But here the White House account of the terror threat and the account actually laid out in the NIE seemed to diverge.
The question is how Iraq fits into the overall terror threat.
The new NIE talks about al-Qaida in Iraq and calls it core al-Qaida's most visible and capable affiliate.
The NIE says core al-Qaida, based in Pakistan, may try to use its Iraqi branch for recruitment or to energize Sunni extremists.
But the NIE does not suggest al-Qaida in Iraq has the capability to attack the U.S.
Ted Gistaro.
The community judges that the overwhelming amount of AQI resources at present are focused on the conflict in Iraq.
In other words, their resources are not focused on attacking the U.S.
So how to square that with the president's view that, as he puts it, the U.S.
is fighting terrorists in Iraq so they won't attack us at home?
Critics suggest that the Bush administration is deliberately confusing al-Qaida in Iraq, a group that did not exist before the U.S.
invasion with Osama bin Laden's group.
Back at the White House, an exasperated-sounding Fran Townsend argued, there's no confusion.
It's the same organization.
